body:
I can reproduce this with the following code:

```
# crash2.py
import mxnet as mx
import numpy as np


def crash2():
    num_rows, num_cols = 100, 100

    kv = mx.kvstore.create('dist_sync')
    kv.init(0, mx.nd.zeros((num_cols, num_cols)))

    ans = mx.ndarray.ones((num_cols, num_cols))
    kv.push(0, ans)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    crash2()
```

running using the ```launcher.py``` command:

```
mxnet/tools/launch.py -n4 --launcher ssh -H hosts python crash2.py
```

It doesn't happen every time with that command. Maybe 20% of the time.

I'm debugging this now, will update if I can find a fix.
This is to be tracked to #5463

@qiyuangong 

Can you please share your insights on this issue.
get it , thank you~

Actually, I am not an expert in deep learning (I am still trying to be :) ).  Here are some suggestions:

First, your result seems not good enough, even in `sync` model. Normally, it should be more than 96% with default parameters. Use `export PS_VERBOSE=1; your current command` to print more details. (`PS_VERBOSE=2` will print more)

Second, you can debug locally on your machine, with 'local' model (But you have to kill process manually when they go wrong). The basic workflow is the same as `yarn`, but run locally in different processes. Aforementioned `export PS_VERBOSE=1` also works in `local` model.

Also, as mentioned by MXNet members in #5422, distributed training is meaningless in small datasets. It seems that they have not added warnings in docs yet.
This pull request is ready for review now.
Thanks for your insights. Will try your suggestions and get back.

I don't mean the iterator's batches

@guotong1988 

**First of all, all subprocesses or working nodes are launched with nearly the same command and parameters. So, how do they make sure they act just like we want?** 
The answer is the MXNet using `envs` to specify roles and other parameters, e.g., `env['DMLC_ROLE'] = 'scheduler'` means launch a `scheduler` process.

**Let's go back and see the whole workflow.** 

1. When you are submitting tasks with `tools/launch.py`, MXNet will redirect it to a specific script such as `ssh.py` according to your `--launch parameter`.  Let's use ssh as an example.
2. Then, **all** these scripts will call `submit` defined in  `tracker.py`. In most cases, this submit function will try to init and launch a `PSTracker` (actually, it just write a few envs, e.g, `env['DMLC_ROLE'] = 'scheduler'`, and run the command you give). 
3. Then, it stores scheduler's **IP and port to `envs` ( `DMLC_PS_ROOT_URI ` and `DMLC_PS_ROOT_PORT `)**, such that `worker` and `server` can communicate or register with `scheduler`.
4. `ssh_submit` function in `ssh.py` is called by `tracker.py` (remember you have passed a function to tracker.submit). Note that envs are passed to this submit function.  This function will try to launch `worker` and `server` with given command and `envs`.  For worker nodes, their roles are  `env['DMLC_ROLE'] = 'woker'`.
@Ldpe2G thanks for reminding this, just committed the changes

Personally, I suggest running distributed training with `--launch local`, which launch all nodes with subprocess, so you can debug locally. Use `export PS_VERBOSE=1` or `export PS_VERBOSE=2` to print more detail.  The only drawback is that you have to kill all processes manually when something goes wrong.

I know that you can set more than one num_server, but it is not clear to me why it is needed, how it is used and how it is implemented. My understanding is that the scheduler resides on the server and that there is only one scheduler thus one server in the architecture. Does this num_server correspond to distributed KV_STORE?

@sxjscience @piiswrong I think the problem is related with the issues (numerical computation issue) in these links: [https://github.com/fchollet/keras/issues/511](https://github.com/fchollet/keras/issues/511 ) and [https://github.com/fchollet/keras/issues/1244](https://github.com/fchollet/keras/issues/1244). They couldn't reach a stable solution, too. Theano has nanguardmode solution which I don't know its effectiveness. An efficient solution for the numerical computation stability would be good. For now, I'll apply the suggestions mentioned in [http://deeplearning.net/software/theano/tutorial/nan_tutorial.html](http://deeplearning.net/software/theano/tutorial/nan_tutorial.html). Just FYI.

@mcxkarakoc For this example, I feel that the input here is one issue for the unstable behavior.
```python
data = mx.nd.normal(loc=74.0131, scale=61.9225, shape=(8192, 12288));
data = data - 74.0131
```
This means that data will be non-centered and the sigmoids are at the saturate region.

Also, the hidden nodes of FC layer is quite large and may cause some computational problems.
@yudeshui Could you confirm that this works in your case? If that is so, I can PR this first and doc the incorrect behavior for multi-GPU training.

According to  https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/__init__.py#L52, and your code
`Model    = mx.mod.Module(
        symbol=Model_Net,
        context=Devices,
        data_names=['data'],
        label_names=['softmax_label']
    )`

You are already using `module`.

@bigdata2

I think you means `export DMLC_NUM_SERVER=$1`, which is located in `local.sh`.

`DMLC_NUM_SERVER ` is used to set number of `servers` (parameter server) launched during distributed training (when kvstore is set to be `dist_sync` or `dist_async`). 

For more details, you can search for `parameter server`. But, currently, we don't need to worry about this parameter. MXNet documents recommend us to use `tool/launch.py`  with `-n num` parameter, which launches `num` servers and `num` workers (with 1 `scheduler` launched in client side).

Well, these details are hidden in messes of docs (http://mxnet.io/how_to/multi_devices.html) and codes (https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tools/launch.py#L53). I found these details by reading docs, codes and papers (http://www.cs.cmu.edu/~muli/file/parameter_server_osdi14.pdf).

Where am I wrong ?

if i understand correctly, we put ops in contrib if they are new and not well tested. once they are mature, we will consider to move them into core. 

then do we really want to have `contrib` in `mx.sym.contrib.xxx`? if we move the ops, 
then users need to update their codes.
contrib is for things that we don't give backward compatibility promise. When ops move to core interface/behavior may change

This is the source of the function that you trying to use, just read it and understand what it is expecting of you. This is all pretty simple python.
```
    def predict(self, eval_data, num_batch=None, merge_batches=True, reset=True,
                always_output_list=False):
        """Run prediction and collect the outputs.

        When `merge_batches` is `True` (by default), the return value will be a list
        `[out1, out2, out3]`.  Where each element is concatenation of the outputs for
        all the mini-batches. If further that `always_output_list` is `False` (by default),
        then in the case of a single output, `out1` is returned instead of `[out1]`.

        When `merge_batches` is `False`, the return value will be a nested list like
        `[[out1_batch1, out2_batch1], [out1_batch2], ...]`. This mode is useful because
        in some cases (e.g. bucketing), the module does not necessarily produce the same
        number of outputs.

        The objects in the results are `NDArray`s. If you need to work with numpy array,
        just call `.asnumpy()` on each of the `NDArray`.

        Parameters
        ----------
        eval_data : DataIter
        num_batch : int
            Default is `None`, indicating running all the batches in the data iterator.
        merge_batches : bool
            Default is `True`, see the doc for return values.
        reset : bool
            Default is `True`, indicating whether we should reset the data iter before start
            doing prediction.
        always_output_list : bool
            Default is `False`, see the doc for return values.

        Returns
        -------
        list of NDArray or list of list of NDArray
            Predict results

        Examples
        --------
        An example of using predict for prediction::
        >>> #Predict on the first 10 batches of val_dataiter
        >>> mod.predict(eval_data=val_dataiter, num_batch=10)
        """
assert self.binded and self.params_initialized

        if reset:
            eval_data.reset()

        output_list = []

        for nbatch, eval_batch in enumerate(eval_data):
            if num_batch is not None and nbatch == num_batch:
                break
            self.forward(eval_batch, is_train=False)
            pad = eval_batch.pad
            outputs = [out[0:out.shape[0]-pad].copy() for out in self.get_outputs()]

            output_list.append(outputs)

        if len(output_list) == 0:
            return output_list

        if merge_batches:
            num_outputs = len(output_list[0])
            for out in output_list:
                assert len(out) == num_outputs, \
                       'Cannot merge batches, as num of outputs is not the same ' + \
                       'in mini-batches. Maybe bucketing is used?'
            output_list2 = [ndarray.concatenate([out[i] for out in output_list])
                            for i in range(num_outputs)]

            if num_outputs == 1 and not always_output_list:
                return output_list2[0]
            return output_list2

        return output_list
```
In my case, removing this linking flag works. I think this flag should only be used with opencv of version 3.0.

Hi, I have solved the problem. I have built the latest release of MxNet toegther. I cloned the code for the C++ API through a link on the MxNet website. These two or not compatible! You need to download/clone the latest version of the C++ API from Github. For the rest the procedure for installing etc. remains the same. Basically only the header files are different between the 2 c++ API versions.

I recently fixed a race condition in pthreadpool (see Maratyszcza/pthreadpool@630dfb6638927df1f3181eee339662a86b3cea0b), the threading library used by NNPACK. This race condition sometimes resulted in deadlock. If you use an earlier pthreadpool version, this is the likely cause of your problem.

This is caused by pad value not provided when BucketSentenceIter.next() returns DataBatch. Just add pad=0 to BucketSentenceIter.next() like:
`return DataBatch([data], [label], pad=0,
                         bucket_key=self.buckets[i],
                         provide_data=[(self.data_name, data.shape)],
                         provide_label=[(self.label_name, label.shape)])`
